original.definition: pick out, select, or choose from a number of alternatives

sememes.reasoning: The verb 'choose' describes an action that results in a change of status for the chosen item, moving it from a set of alternatives to a state of being selected. This is a change in relation or status.

participants.reasoning: The 'Somebody' in the verb frame is the entity that intentionally performs the act of choosing.
The 'something' in the verb frame is the item that is selected or chosen.
The definition explicitly states 'from a number of alternatives', indicating the source or context from which the patient is selected.

Evidentiality.reasoning: The act of choosing is typically a direct experience for the agent or observable by others.

Mood.reasoning: The verb's core meaning is declarative, stating an action or event.

Modality.reasoning: The presence of an agent ('Somebody') performing the action implies a strong will and intention behind the choice.

Polarity.reasoning: The act of choosing itself is semantically neutral; its positive or negative valence depends on the context or the item chosen.

Volitionality.reasoning: The frame 'Somebody select something' clearly indicates a volitional agent performing an intentional action.

Confidence.reasoning: Once a choice is made, the fact of the choice is definite and certain.

Iterativity.reasoning: Choosing describes a single, discrete event of making a selection, even if selections can be made multiple times.

participants.reasoning: value_type 'alternatives.n.01' is not a valid synset in NLTK.

candidates.description: a course that the student can select from among alternatives (gloss match)
a switch that is used to select among alternatives (gloss match)
the superior one of two alternatives (gloss match)
doubt concerning two or more possible alternatives or courses of action (gloss match)
(electronics) a system design that duplicates components to provide alternatives in case one component fails (gloss match)
an analysis of the cost effectiveness of different alternatives in order to see whether the benefits outweigh the costs (gloss match)
analysis of a problem into alternative possibilities followed by the systematic rejection of unacceptable alternatives (gloss match)
the more conspicuous of two alternatives or cases or sides (gloss match)
an inclination to favor one group or view or opinion over alternatives (gloss match)
a document listing the alternatives that is used in voting (gloss match)
cost in terms of foregoing alternatives (gloss match)

participants.corrected_reasoning: LLM suggestion: Replaced invalid 'alternatives.n.01' with the semantically equivalent and valid 'alternative.n.01' which means 'one of a number of things from which only one can be chosen'.
